52.4 hours, every achievement unlocked, all DLC completed‚Äîand honestly, every minute was worth it. Dark Souls 3 was the second Souls game I played, and it delivered exactly what I wanted from the series. The boss fights were intense and memorable, the world design felt interconnected and atmospheric, and the combat struck a perfect balance between classic Souls weight and faster, more aggressive action.
Out of all the Souls and Souls-like games I‚Äôve played so far, DS3 lands as my 3rd favorite, but that still puts it in incredible company. It‚Äôs polished, challenging in all the right ways, and consistently rewarding. If you enjoy difficult but fair combat, amazing DLC content, and that signature FromSoftware sense of progression, this game is absolutely worth diving into‚Äîespecially if you‚Äôre the type who loves fully completing a game.

I was very excited to get into my replay of Dark Souls 3, as I remember loving it back when it released. The first thing that stood out to me, though, going straight from Dark Souls 2 to 3, was how much better the movement and combat felt. It felt much more responsive, much less restricted, and overall fluid. It led me to enjoy the early game a lot, but before I knew it, I was nearing the end. This was the one thing stopping me from liking this as much as the first game in the series. I love most of the bosses here, and the areas look fantastic, and many of them are a blast to explore. Just running around the place looking for secrets while blasting Agalloch will stay with me for a while. The game is a very atmospheric experience, but it also feels like it ends just as it was really getting started.

The game begins with one of my favourite bosses in the series. Iudex Gundyr is a fantastic tutorial fight, almost as good as Father Gascoigne. It teaches you the differences between DS3 and the previous games through combat. It‚Äôs a bit faster-paced, with more wind-ups, more attacks, and more unexpected elements. It prepares you for what‚Äôs to come expertly. There isn‚Äôt a boss as good as this in the game until the Abyss Watchers, but I was ok with that due to the still high quality found in the bosses in between. Other bosses that I love from this game include: Pontiff, Dancer of Boreal Valley, Dragonslayer Armour, Champion Gundyr, Lothric, Nameless King (just the 2nd half, fuck the first half), Soul of Cinder, Sister Friede, and of course, Slave Knight Gael. So yeah, a lot. The consistency of the boss pool for this game is very high, which I greatly appreciated coming off Dark Souls 2.

The locations themselves I adore as well. They‚Äôre huge, dense, and full of details that can be easily missed. It makes the world and lore feel that much more real. My favourite area is just anything related to Lothric Castle, but returning to Anor Londo was incredible, and The Ringed City is both terrifying and artistically mesmerising. Speaking of, this was my first time going through the DLC for the game. I never got around to them when I originally played the game, but I‚Äôm kinda glad I waited. Getting to experience The Ringed City for the first time was jaw-dropping. Going to another painted world was nice as well. Aesthetically, I like the area a lot, but I definitely found The Ringed City more compelling.

The game isn‚Äôt without its faults, though; there are bosses I don‚Äôt like and even hate. Yhorm is a disappointing fight, and the same can be said about Wolnir. The boss I hate the most here, though, is King of the Storm, the first half of Nameless King. I think I hate this fight more than I would solely due to it being a part of one of the best fights in the game. I‚Äôm not fond of having to fight an oversized chicken with awful hitboxes and terrible design before I get to fight something fantastic. I feel like if they shrunk King of the Storm‚Äôs model and fixed the hitbox issues, I would be ok with the fight. It still wouldn‚Äôt be great, but it‚Äôd be much better than what we got.

I think the main thing that keeps this from being as good as the first game in the series is that I didn‚Äôt feel satisfied by the end. I finished the fight with Lothric, thinking I had just finished the 2nd act of the game, when in reality, I was close to being done. It felt like there should‚Äôve been many more full areas in the game before Soul of Cinder. I haven‚Äôt felt this way about any of the other FromSoft Soulslike games they‚Äôve released. In fact, a lot of the time it‚Äôs the other way around. I usually feel a lot of them overstay their welcome. Especially Dark Souls 2 and Elden Ring. But here I felt disappointed that there wasn‚Äôt more. This might come across as ‚ÄúI really enjoyed this game, why isn‚Äôt there more of it?‚Äù but it‚Äôs more like ‚ÄúI really wanted more from this game because it feels like it was cut short.‚Äù. Other than that, this is a game very close to fantastic, and I‚Äôm glad I revisited it. Oh yeah, whoever decided on the achievements for this game seriously needs to question their design philosophy because holy shit do some of them suck so much. Elden Ring replay is next, hope I enjoy it more this time around.

Dark Souls III is the best Dark Souls game.

The extreme difficulty remains balanced throughout whilst punishing mistakes and greediness. The boss fights are excellent with a few exceptions. The hardest bosses are in the two DLCs with some having up to three phases! These bosses are accompanied by an impeccable soundtrack.

The game in general feels a lot smoother and faster paced compared to Dark Souls II with the level design being less confusing. Boss runbacks have been reduced with heavy emphasis on shortcuts, with the longest being Oceiros, the Consumed King at one minute fifteen seconds and the shortest being Slave Knight Gael at four seconds! There is Dark Souls 1 nostalgia included here, such as the return of Blacksmith Andre, Anor Londo, Asylum Demon and Capra Demon corpses scattered throughout Smouldering Lake, as well as the Stone Demon enemy from Lost Izalith. 

The "Focus Points" (FP) system returns from Demon's Souls to perform miracles, sorceries, pyromancies and weapon/shield "Skills" which allow for special attacks and abilities. Performing these actions drain your FP bar, which is the blue line underneath the red HP bar. FP doesn't regenerate, so you have to consume an Ashen Estus Flask. You can choose whether you would rather have more Estus Flasks (for healing) or Ashen Estus Flasks by talking to Blacksmith Andre.

The poetic storytelling makes a return with a very worthy final boss of the base game and both DLCs. NPC side quests make a return, with most worth pursuing to acquire certain items, such as a Titanite Slab, Silvercat Ring and the Pyromancy Flame being the most useful.

Dark Souls III contains new additions such as a red cross next to weapons that you don't have the correct stats for. The Homeward Bone can take you to Firelink Shrine or the last Bonfire rested at, unlike previous Dark Souls games. Upgrading armour sets have been removed. A new stat called "Luck" has been added which is useful for farming rare Covenant items and upgrade materials. Estus soup is a new healing station that refills your HP, but there are only three of them in Lothric.

Alas, covenants in this game don't benefit PvE as they're more suited to PvP, unlike previous Dark Souls games.

Dark Souls III is the secret lovechild of Bloodborne and Dark Souls [1]. The story proves to be a direct sequel to the first title of the trilogy, whole amping up the gameplay and pacing to something more akin to but still not quite Bloodborne. This proves to be both a boon and a hinderance, leaving the game in a state that may turn off fans of the aforementioned titles--or at least hinder the experience.

  Firstly, the gameplay is of a faster pace than Dark Souls or Dark Souls 2. While heavier armor and weaponry can still bring about slower pacing, and the shield is still very effective throughout the game, the enemy and boss movements and speed require greater speed than the Chosen Undead or Bearer of the Curse are capable of. Perhaps this is not a direct result of From Software previously working on Bloodborne, and may well be a result of modern innovation. The fact of the matter is, the enemy and especially boss experience feels more familiar to a Bloodborne player than a Dark Souls player. Even some of the NPC designs and the human trees look like something out of Yharnam or the Nightmare realm. While this game does still require a fair level of patience, it is far more forgiving and even rewarding than Dark Souls for rushing. Even the bonfires are plentiful, removing the challenge of boss runs or bonfire runs. With the absence of a Lord Vessel, and the game immediately allowing for fast travel as soon as you've found the Shrine Bonfire, it makes the overabundance of bonfires redundant--in one instance, you acquire a bonfire after defeating a boss, then immediately find one within staring distance a safe walk away. Perhaps this was in order to make the game more welcoming to gamers unfamiliar with the Soul's Like genre. Even Bloodborne didn't have lanterns so congested together in the game, and it's supposed to be fast paced.

Despite these similarities and gripes, the world building is just as masterful as is to be expected from From Software. The story is far more connected to the first title than Dark Souls 2 in its entirety, and acts as a direct sequel to Dark Souls. Even one of the bosses is an allusion to every player character ever created for, and who has completed the first game. The Knights of Katarina make a return, and we have references to the NPCs and even bosses from the first game and its DLC. Not to spoil where, but an area from Dark Souls is revisited in this game, altered ever so slightly to keep the familiarity while playing up the passage of time and events on the wear and tear of the setting. The story is truly compelling, and interacting with the various NPCs or reading the item descriptions really immerses one into the story.

  Now second, the game has some unfair hitboxes, and enemies that the first game would have made parry-able cannot be. This experience really takes out the point of even learning how to parry--outside of dealing with mobs--since the game does not bother testing all that it has taught you the way the first does. The final boss in particular, while being a parallel to Lord Gwyn, cannot be parried despite being design like the type of bosses that usually can. For a final boss, you would expect the game's mechanics to be put to the test. You can parry Lord Gwyn, and are even given Black Knights outside of his fog door to practice on. You can parry Gehrman, The First Hunter, for he is a hunter just like you. The final boss in Dark Souls 3, despite being humanoid, cannot be parried. Pile that together with certain mechanics to the boss fight, unfair hitboxes--check out YouTube videos that show the hitboxes--and several combos that can one shot you without wearing specific rings or using a miracle or min-maxing your vigor, and you're left with a final boss that can leave a sour taste in your mouth after you conclude the game. The final optional boss would have served as a better final boss, despite being much more difficult. Despite these complaints, its lore almost makes up entirely for it. Almost. Thankfully, you can enlist a summon if you follow a specific questline, or even summon other players. The boss run is also the most direct and peaceful in the game, but just keep the challenge ahead in mind when plotting your attributes.

  In conclusion, Dark Souls III is a game that I would recommend only to fans of Dark Souls or Bloodborne--who have already completed either of both games, and are looking for more akin to it--however I would not recommend it as anyone's first From Software game. If you can only choose one from the Dark Souls trilogy to ever play, I find the first to be a greater experience all the way through to completion, however I do recommend playing Dark Souls III afterward if you do decide to try another game. For a faster pace, I recommend getting a PS4 and playing Bloodborne instead of starting with Dark Souls III, and I wouldn't recommend going back unless you are ready to adjust to a slower pace.

Creative Bankruptcy: The Game
They fixed and unfixed many of the issues with Dark Souls II.
They kept power stancing, because it obviously makes sense to include that. They also added weapons which were made specifically to be used with both hands, like the Sellsword Twinblades and the Drang Hammers. But obviously, the coolest one is the Farron Greatsword. Its name doesn't make much sense considering that it's a dagger and an actual sword, but hey, cool, regardless.
Which is why it's so dumb that they made the player character mainly right handed, just like in the first Dark Souls. For example, holding an axe in your left hand makes you block, and you can only do a heavy attack with it. Meanwhile, if you have a shield in your right hand, you start punching with it. In Dark Souls II, your character is ambidextrous, however, sometimes you deal less damage with the left hand.
As for the story, areas, and story, the game tries its hardest to emulate Dark Souls 1, from the main quest to the ending, the boss designs, and the levels.
Crystal Sage is just Pinwheel that's not too easy. Old Demon King is just Demon Firesage from DS1. Wolnir is basically Gravelord Nito, again, from DS1. Yhorm the Giant has to be defeated with the Stormruler, a weapon from Demon's Souls, used specifically to defeat the Storm King, a boss fight, that is actually really fun with a cool setting. Dragonslayer Armour is basically the Penetrator from Demon's Souls. Champion Gundyr could be a different version of Iudex Gundyr that the developers thought would be cool, but couldn't decide on which one to put in the game. Soul of Cinder is literally the the Burnt Ivory King from Dark Souls II's Crown of the Ivory King DLC. Same moveset, almost the same attacks. As for the DLCs, Halflight is, again, literally just the Old Monk from Demon's Souls with the same invasion gimmick (which is quite cool). Then Slave Knight Gael, who is a red Artorias.
Areas: Firelink Shrine, same name and function as DS1, but a different setting. I like this version more. Farron Keep => Blighttown. Catacombs of Carthus => Catacombs from DS1. Irithyll + Anor Londo => Anor Londo. Grand Archives => The Duke's Archives. Untended Graves is funny because there's an extremely difficult out of bounds glitch where you can climb up backwards from Cemetery of Ash to reach the illusory wall to reach Untended Graves, but I think you'd get stuck as you probably can't enter the fog wall from the other side (at least in DS2 you couldn't do that), but if you drop back down you'd arrive in Untended Graves. Archdragon Peak is great, especially the Nameless King, I'd say he's my favourite boss. Kiln of the First Flame, same name as in DS1. Painted World of Ariandel => Painted World from DS1. So the pattern here is to evoke an emotion from the better designed game, DS1, by copying everything they can, but making them much smaller, and making them look just as terrible as they were in DS1, because of technical limitations.
More about the bosses (and the enemies), oh dear. It seems like they just tried to make them difficult for the sake of it. They fixed and unfixed many of the issues with Dark Souls II.
They kept power stancing, because it obviously makes sense to include that. They also added weapons which were made specifically to be used with both hands, like the Sellsword Twinblades and the Drang Hammers. But obviously, the coolest one is the Farron Greatsword. Its name doesn't make much sense considering that it's a dagger and an actual sword, but hey, cool, regardless.
Which is why it's so dumb that they made the player character mainly right handed, just like in the first Dark Souls. For example, holding an axe in your left hand makes you block, and you can only do a heavy attack with it. Meanwhile, if you have a shield in your right hand, you start punching with it. In Dark Souls II, your character is ambidextrous, however, sometimes you deal less damage with the left hand.
As for the story, areas, and story, the game tries its hardest to emulate Dark Souls 1, from the main quest to the ending, the boss designs, and the levels.
Crystal Sage is just Pinwheel that's not too easy. Old Demon King is just Demon Firesage from DS1. Wolnir is basically Gravelord Nito, again, from DS1. Yhorm the Giant has to be defeated with the Stormruler, a weapon from Demon's Souls, used specifically to defeat the Storm King, a boss fight, that is actually really fun with a cool setting. Dragonslayer Armour is basically the Penetrator from Demon's Souls. Champion Gundyr could be a different version of Iudex Gundyr that the developers thought would be cool, but couldn't decide on which one to put in the game. Soul of Cinder is literally the the Burnt Ivory King from Dark Souls II's Crown of the Ivory King DLC. Same moveset, almost the same attacks. As for the DLCs, Halflight is, again, literally just the Old Monk from Demon's Souls with the same invasion gimmick (which is quite cool). Then Slave Knight Gael, who is a red Artorias.
Areas: Firelink Shrine, same name and function as DS1, but a different setting. I like this version more. Farron Keep => Blighttown. Catacombs of Carthus => Catacombs from DS1. Irithyll + Anor Londo => Anor Londo. Grand Archives => The Duke's Archives. Untended Graves is funny because there's an extremely difficult out of bounds glitch where you can climb up backwards from Cemetery of Ash to reach the illusory wall to reach Untended Graves, but I think you'd get stuck as you probably can't enter the fog wall from the other side (at least in DS2 you couldn't do that), but if you drop back down you'd arrive in Untended Graves. Archdragon Peak is great, especially the Nameless King, I'd say he's my favourite boss. Kiln of the First Flame, same name as in DS1. Painted World of Ariandel => Painted World from DS1. So the pattern here is to evoke an emotion from the better designed game, DS1, by copying everything they can, but making them much smaller, and making them look just as terrible as they were in DS1, because of technical limitations.
More about the bosses (and the enemies), oh dear. It seems like they just tried to make them difficult for the sake of it. They all aggressively ambush you in hordes, as if this was Left 4 Dead or something. Two perfect examples of creative bankruptcy are the Deacons of the Deep and High Lord Wolnir. The deacons are just enemies spawning infinitely without giving you any room for movement at all, and the first stage of the fight is just some collective soul that you can only deal an exact amount of damage to. Then the second stage which is just a crowd crush simulator. Then there's Wolnir, a hard to reach boss with incredibly high defence, whose weakness are his bracelets. Then there's the mist around him, which can make reaching the bracelet on his right hand challenging, because it pretty much instantly kills you. If he starts moving upwards, you're basically dead. Dragonslayer Armour can be pretty difficult by itself, especially because you're fighting on a bridge, and then for some reason the level designers also decided to put some monster in the sky to shoot at you during the second phase. Why? The rest are fine, I guess. It'd be silly to complain about attacks with weird timing. They're annoying, but they're fine.
Magic works the same way as it did in Demon's Souls, meaning you have a mana bar, that you can refill with items (here, mainly the Ashen Estus Flask). I like this one more than the system in DS1 and 2.
As for armour, this is the only game in the series where you can't upgrade armour. Which is sad for cosplay builds, as now you have to choose between high defence or fashion. Meh.
Weapon infusion also works the same way as it does in DS2, which I'm quite fond of.
As for PvP, there aren't really any OP builds like in DS1, but it's still just as unforgiving. Parrying is more difficult (with regular shields?) and rolling i-frames are longer. Parrying would be fine with latency, but dodging with server delay just makes fighting a nightmare. At least you can FINALLY invade without being embered/in human form. Thank GOD.
Overall, this game is a bit of a disappointment for me.
